The Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 2.raw_text: The Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208, Section 28, provide the court with the authority to modify custody orders based on the best interests of the child.
The Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 2.proposition: The Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208, Section 28, provide the court with the authority to modify custody orders based on the best interests of the child.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Relevant case law, including but not limited to Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002), emphasize that the primary consideration in custody matters is the child's best interests, taking into account their age, needs, and preferences.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames both the custody and removal questions in terms of the children’s best interests, and discusses those interests with reference to the children’s needs (emotional, physical, developmental), circumstances, and to some extent their wishes. It expressly interprets the governing statute as requiring that removal be in the child’s best interests and describes the best‑interests inquiry as the paramount concern in custody/removal decisions. This aligns with the proposition that the primary consideration in custody matters is the child’s best interests, taking account of age, needs, and preferences.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child. … [T]he best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern.”

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).proposition: Relevant case law, including but not limited to Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002), emphasize that the primary consideration in custody matters is the child's best interests, taking into account their age, needs, and preferences.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).support_reasoning: The case is not a custody case but a grandparent-visitation constitutional challenge; however, the court repeatedly relies on and incorporates the traditional Massachusetts "best interests of the child" standard used in custody and visitation matters, expressly citing Yannas as an example of how "best interests" governs such decisions. The opinion confirms that best interests—considering welfare and potential harm to the child—is the controlling standard in this domain, which is broadly consistent with the proposition, though it does not specifically detail age, needs, and preferences in this excerpt.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).relevant_excerpt: "The statute adopts the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the test for determining visitation. This standard has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation and other issues relating to child welfare. The statute, however, uses the standard in a new context... As we have mentioned, an appellate court may, in an appropriate case, construe a statute to render it constitutional. See, e.g., Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710-712 (1985) (discussing relevant factors bearing on ‘best interests’ of children...)."

Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.proposition: Additionally, the case of Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2014), highlights the importance of a child's evolving needs as they grow older, supporting the modification of custody orders to reflect changing circumstances.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion is about the Probate and Family Court’s inherent authority to appoint parenting coordinators and the limits on delegating judicial power, not about modifying custody orders due to children’s evolving needs. The only discussion of modification standards (material and substantial change and best interests) is to emphasize that a parenting coordinator cannot be delegated that statutory role. The case does not analyze or highlight a child’s changing needs as a basis for modifying custody, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.relevant_excerpt: “By statute, if a party seeks a modification of a final judgment of divorce, a judge may make a judgment modifying his or her earlier judgment provided the judge finds that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28. No such standard governs the parent coordinator in the order at issue in this case.”
